metadata.case_name: Abdus Sukkur v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Order made by District Magistrate Burdwan on February 10, 1971 under section 3 of the West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970 (Act No. 19 of 1970) for detention of Abdus Sukkur to prevent him from acting in manner prejudicial to maintenance of public order.
Abdus Sukkur found absconding after detention order and arrested on September 24, 1971; served with detention order, grounds of detention, and vernacular translation.
District Magistrate sent report to State Government on February 10, 1971 about detention order with particulars; State Government approved on February 18, 1971.
State Government placed case before Advisory Board on October 23, 1971.
State Government received representation from petitioner against detention on October 28, 1971.
State Government considered and rejected representation on November 24, 1971 (27 days after receipt); representation then sent to Advisory Board.
Advisory Board, after considering material and hearing petitioner in person, sent report on November 26, 1971 opining sufficient cause for detention.
State Government confirmed detention order on December 1, 1971.
Petitioner filed writ petition under Article 32 through jail to challenge detention.
Initial affidavit in opposition by State Government did not explain 27-day delay in considering representation; matter adjourned on May 5, 1972 for additional affidavit.
On May 24, 1972, counsel for State stated no additional affidavit to be filed; delay remained unexplained.

legal_issues.text: Whether unexplained delay of 27 days by State Government in considering and rejecting the petitioner's representation against detention invalidates the detention under Article 22(5) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Challenged detention on ground of unexplained delay in considering representation.

respondent_arguments.text: No specific arguments detailed; failed to explain delay despite opportunity.

court_reasoning.text: Unexplained delay of 27 days in considering and rejecting representation received on October 28, 1971 until November 24, 1971 invalidates detention as it contravenes Article 22(5) requiring prompt consideration to afford earliest opportunity for representation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delay remained unexplained as no additional affidavit filed.

court_reasoning.text: Article 22(5) implies representation must be dealt with promptly; undue delay reduces constitutional safeguard to farce.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Liberty of subject requires strict compliance.

court_reasoning.text: String of precedents establish unexplained delay vitiates detention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Immediate consideration imperative as personal liberty at stake.

holdings.text: Unexplained delay in disposal of detenu's representation introduces serious infirmity, rendering detention illegal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Government bound to consider representation expeditiously; delay of 47 days (June 23 to Aug 9, 1969) held infraction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khairul Haque v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.citation: P. No. 246 of 1969, decided on September 10, 1969
precedents_cited.relevance: Article 22(5) requires independent and expeditious consideration by Government and Advisory Board.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prof. K. L. Singh v. State of Manipur
precedents_cited.relevance: Unexplained delay of 17 days renders detention illegal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baidya Nath Chunkar v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.citation: W.P. No. 377 of 1971, decided on March 14, 1972
precedents_cited.relevance: Unexplained delay of 29 days vitiates detention.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kant Lal Bose v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.citation: W.P. No. 8 of 1972, decided on May 5, 1972
precedents_cited.relevance: Unexplained delay of 28 days invalidates detention.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970
statutes_cited.relevance: Authority for detention order by District Magistrate.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Article 22(5) mandates prompt consideration of representation; Article 32 basis for writ petition.

outcome.summary: Petition accepted; rule made absolute; petitioner ordered to be set at liberty forthwith due to unexplained delay in considering representation vitiating detention.

key_quotes.text: Undue delay on the part of the detaining authority in disposing of the said representation would run counter to the underlying object of clause 5 of article 22.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is established beyond any measure of doubt that the appropriate authority is bound to consider the representation of the detenu as early as possible.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The personal liberty of a person is at stake. Any delay would not only be an irresponsible act... but also unconstitutional.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights stakes involved in preventive detention.
